cntk.utils package¶

Submodules¶

cntk.utils.persist module¶

load_model(data_type, filename, device=None)[source]¶

Load the network in model_file, that has been saved using :func:save_model.

Parameters:
  • data_type ('float' or 'double', or NumPy type) – data type of the operation
  • filename (str) – filename to load the model from
  • device (cntk.DeviceDescriptor, default to default device) – instance of DeviceDescriptor
Returns:

root node
save_model(root_op, filename)[source]¶

Save the network of root_op in model_file.

Parameters:
  • root_op (:class:cntk.functions.Function) – op of the graph to save
  • filename (str) – filename to store the model in

cntk.utils.swig_helper module¶

typemap(f)[source]¶

Upcasts Swig types to cntk types that inherit from Swig.

Module contents¶

cntk_device(device_id)[source]¶

Converts the legacy device ID as it was used in CNTK 1 to CNTK DeviceDescriptor instance.

Parameters:device_id (int) – device id, -1 for CPU, 0 or higher for GPU
Returns:CNTK DeviceDescriptor

dense_to_str(data)[source]¶
ensure_dev(ndav, dev)[source]¶
eval(op, arguments=None, precision=None, device=None, backward_pass=False)[source]¶

It evaluates op on the data provided by the reader. This is useful mainly to explore the operators and for convenient unit testing.

Parameters:
  • op (Function) – operation to evaluate
  • arguments (dict or list or tuple) –

    maps variables to their input data. The interpretation depends on the input type:

    • dict: keys are input variable or names and values are the input data.
    • list: elements are input data in the order their respective variables have been defined in the network.

    In both cases, every every sample in the data will be interpreted as a new sequence. To mark samples as continuations of the previous sequence, specify arguments as tuple: the first element will be used as arguments, and the second one will be used as a list of bools, denoting whether a sequence is a new one (True) or a continuation of the previous one (False). Data should be either NumPy arrays or a cntk.io.MinibatchData instance.

  • seq_starts (list of bool`s or `None) – if None, every sequence is treated as a new sequence. Otherwise, it is interpreted as a list of Booleans that tell whether a sequence is a new sequence (True) or a continuation of the previous one (False)
  • precision (str or None) – precision being ‘float32’, ‘float64’, or None, in which case it will be determined by inspecting the operator (costly)
  • device (cntk.DeviceDescriptor) – the device the descriptor, whether it is CPU or GPU (and which one)
  • backward_pass (bool, optional) – whether a backward pass is performed
Returns:

mapping of output variables to their values.
get_data_type(*args)[source]¶

Calculates the highest precision numpy datatype of the provided parameters. If the parameter is a Function instance, it calculates it based on its inputs.

Parameters:args (number, list, NumPy array, Variable, or Function) – input
Returns:np.float32 or np.float64

  • directory (str) – optional directory, in which the temporary file will
  • created (be) –
Returns:

Filename of the temporary file
get_train_eval_criterion(trainer)[source]¶

Fetch the train evaluation criterion (e.g., classification error) from the last minibatch and copy it to the CPU in case it is on the GPU. :param trainer: the trainer used. :type trainer: Trainer

Returns:the criterion value
get_train_loss(trainer)[source]¶

Fetch the train loss from the last minibatch and copy it to the CPU in case it is on the GPU. :param trainer: the trainer used. :type trainer: Trainer

Returns:the loss value
is_string(value)[source]¶
is_tensor(data)[source]¶

Checks whether the data is a tensor, i.e. whether it is a NumPy array or a list of NumPy arrays.

Parameters:data – data to check

Returns: True, if it is a tensor.

is_tensor_list(data)[source]¶

Checks whether the data is a CNTK sequence, which is expressed in Python as a list of varying sized NumPy objects.

ones_like(batch, precision)[source]¶

Returns a new batch, which has the same format as batch but all values set to 1.

Parameters:batch (list of NumPy arrays) – a list of sequences, which are NumPy arrays
pad_to_dense(batch)[source]¶

Appends the minimal required amount of zeroes at the end of each sample in the batch so that it becomes rectangular. batch is assumed to be row-major: first index is batch item, second is sequence item, then comes that actual sample. The sequence length is assumed to be the only varying dimension.

Parameters:
  • batch (list of NumPy arrays) – list of arrays that differ only in their
  • dimension (first) –
Returns:

Padded NumPy array
sanitize_axis(rank, axis)[source]¶

Sanitizes the axis.

Parameters:
  • rank (int) – rank of the tensor on which axis is to be used
  • axis (:class:Axis or int or None) –

    the axis to be used. * :class:Axis: use axis instance directly (will convert row- to

    col-major in case of static axis.
    • int: if positive, use it as static axis. If negative, count from last to first axis
    • None: denote all available axes
sanitize_batch(var, batch, seq_starts=None, data_type=None, device=None)[source]¶

Convert to :cntk:`Value` with data_type. If the samples in batch have different sequence lengths, pad them to max sequence length and create a mask.

Parameters:
  • var (:class:Variable) – variable node for which the batch is meant
  • batch (list of NumPy arrays) – input
  • seq_starts (list of bool`s or `None) – if None, every sequence is treated as a new sequence. Otherwise, it is interpreted as a list of Booleans that tell whether a sequence is a new sequence (True) or a continuation of the previous one (False)
Returns:

converted batch
Return type:

:class:Value
sanitize_dtype_cntk(dtype)[source]¶
sanitize_dtype_numpy(dtype)[source]¶
sanitize_dynamic_axes(axes)[source]¶
sanitize_function(arg)[source]¶

Tries to retrieve a Function from the argument or throws an exception if that’s not possible.

sanitize_input(arg, fallback_dtype=<class 'numpy.float32'>)[source]¶

Convert to Variable or Constant so that it can be passed as Variable to the CNTK operators.

  • If arg is a NumPy array and its type is neither np.float32 nor
np.float64, it sets it to np.float32.
  • If arg is an op, it is assumed that it has only one output, which will be returned.
Parameters:
  • arg (number, NumPy array, Variable, or Function) – input
  • fallback_dtype (numpy dtype) – fallback dtype in case arg is a list
Returns:

Constant, if arg was a number or NumPy array. Variable otherwise.
sanitize_precision(precision)[source]¶

Converts precision to NumPy precision

Parameters:precision (str or np.float32 or np.float64) – precision, if string it can be one of ‘float’ ‘float32, ‘double’, or ‘float64’
Returns:NumPy precision
sanitize_shape(shape)[source]¶

If shape is scalar, it creates a tuple out of it and reverse it as cntk uses column major.

sanitize_var_map(op_arguments, arguments, precision=None, device=None)[source]¶

Sanitizes a dictionary of Variable`s to input data such that it can be handed off to the `Forward method.

Parameters:
  • op_arguments (cntk.ops.functions.Function) – arguments of the root function. In forward pass it is typically op.arguments(), in backward mode it is op.outputs()
  • arguments (dict or list or tuple) –

    maps variables to their input data. The interpretation depends on the input type:

    • dict: keys are input variable or names and values are the input data.
    • list: elements are input data in the order their respective variables have been defined in the network.

    In both cases, every every sample in the data will be interpreted as a new sequence. To mark samples as continuations of the previous sequence, specify arguments as tuple: the first element will be used as arguments, and the second one will be used as a list of bools, denoting whether a sequence is a new one (True) or a continuation of the previous one (False). Data should be either NumPy arrays or a cntk.io.MinibatchData instance.

  • precision (str or np.float32 or np.float64) – if string it can be one of ‘float’ ‘float32, ‘double’, ‘float64’, or None
  • device (DeviceDescriptor or None) – CNTK DeviceDescriptor
Returns:

dict that maps variables to sanitized batches
sparse_to_str(data)[source]¶
tensors_to_text_format(sample_idx, alias_tensor_map)[source]¶

Converts a list of NumPy arrays representing tensors of inputs into a format that is readable by CNTKTextReader.

Parameters:
  • sample_idx (int) – number of current sample
  • alias_tensor_map (dict) – maps alias (str) to tensor (ndarray). Tensors are assumed to have dynamic axis.
Returns:

String representation in CNTKTextReader format
value_to_seq(value)[source]¶

Convert a Value to a sequence of NumPy arrays that have their masked entries removed.

Parameters:value (Value) – Value as it is returned by Swig
Returns:a list of NumPy arrays
